newsitem.title: USA: Czech premier says banking sector is healthy.
newsitem.headline: Czech premier says banking sector is healthy.

text.p: Czech Prime Minister Vaclav Klaus said on Sunday the country's banking system, which has seen several institutions put under forced administration in recent months, was fragile but healthy.

Asked if there was a crisis in the sector, Klaus told reporters "No. The term crisis is used just by the political leaders and is not a real description of the situation of the banking sector in the Czech Republic."
Analysts have blamed problems in the banking sector for a recent weakening of the Czech crown against the dollar.

But Klaus, premier since 1991, said banks which had encountered problems were "rather small." "Fragility of the system is something natural in a newly-born banking system after 50 years of no banking at all and I am pretty sure that the system is healthy. I'm really not afraid," he said.
The Czech National Bank on Friday gave approval for its administrators of Podnikatelska Banka to settle with ceditors and wind up the bank, CTK news agency reported.

Podnikatelska, with headquarters in Prague and five branches, was put under forced administration in June and shut after losses of more than one billion crowns ($36 million). It was the eighth bank to come under central bank supervision.
Since then, three other banks have been put into forced administration, including Agrobanka, the fifth largest.

Klaus, in an earlier speech to the Institute of International Finance, said the fragility of the banking sector was one of a number of factors keeping real interest rates and margins between interest rates on credits and deposits relatively high.
But Klaus, a champion of pro-market economic transition, said the Czech Republic had completed a difficult stage of transformation after seven years.
"Economic growth of around five percent a year seems to be a feasible middle-term prospect," he said.
The biggest restraint to economic growth was the low rate of unemployment of about three percent which meant labour was short and there was a net inflow of foreign workers.
Relatively high growth had contributed to high domestic demand for imports, creating a significant trade deficit.
The deficit widened to 100.9 billion crowns in January-August from 59.5 billion a year earlier.

"The trade deficit is, therefore considered to be the most important single economic problem of the current period," he said, adding that the Cezch Republic, which is keen to join the European Union, suffered from protectionism in various markets.
Klaus said that despite overall growth, Czechs were starting to see disparities in income and prosperity.
The Czech Republic has carried out a mass privatisation programme which officials in other Eastern European countries, including Russia, have cited as a model.
